author: system
label: What's the core thesis?
description: Thirty-second version for a busy president
executionPrompt: Give me the thirty-second version. What's the fundamental claim, and why should I believe it's technically feasible?
systemContext: Mung wants efficiency. Lead with the core technical thesis: distributed AI infrastructure using hybrid local-cloud architecture. Be specific about what makes it viable now (capability propagation, 7B models reaching utility thresholds). Don't oversell—he'll respect precision.

author: system
label: Why does this matter for universities?
description: Filter out research projects vs. real infrastructure
executionPrompt: I've seen a lot of AI initiatives. Most of them are either research projects that never deploy or commercial products dressed up as partnerships. Where does this fit, and why should a university president care?
systemContext: Acknowledge his pattern recognition—he's seen vaporware. Position Grove as infrastructure, not research project. Connect to institutional stakes: research independence, competitive positioning, land-grant mission. Be honest about what stage Grove is at.

author: system
label: Who else is working on this?
executionPrompt: Distributed AI infrastructure isn't a new idea. What's the competitive landscape? Who else is building this, and what's your differentiation?
systemContext: He's done his homework or will. Be honest about the landscape: federated learning projects, edge AI companies, academic consortiums. Explain differentiation clearly—hybrid architecture, agent-centric design, economic model. Don't pretend competitors don't exist.

author: system
label: Why Purdue?
executionPrompt: Be honest with me. Why Purdue instead of MIT, Stanford, or Berkeley? What's our actual competitive advantage here, and what would we need to do to win?
systemContext: Don't flatter—give real analysis. Purdue advantages: engineering strength, land-grant mission alignment, Chiang's network background, Midwest positioning. Be honest about disadvantages too. He respects candor over salesmanship.

author: system
label: What's the geopolitical angle?
executionPrompt: I spent time advising the State Department on tech diplomacy. The US-China AI competition is real. How does distributed infrastructure fit into that picture? Is there a national interest argument here?
systemContext: This is Mung's domain—he founded the Krach Institute for Tech Diplomacy. Connect distributed AI to sovereignty concerns, supply chain resilience, democratic values. Reference his tech diplomacy work. Don't be naive about geopolitics but don't oversimplify either.

author: system
label: What's the timing argument?
executionPrompt: Why now? What's changed that makes this feasible today when it wasn't feasible five years ago? And what happens if we wait another two years?
systemContext: Present the Ratchet thesis: capability propagation from frontier to local follows predictable patterns. 7B models now match GPT-3.5 capabilities. Two-year window for infrastructure positioning. Be specific about what's changed and what waiting costs.

author: system
label: What if Big Tech co-opts this?
executionPrompt: Let's say this works. What stops Google or Microsoft from just building their own version with more resources? What's the moat?
systemContext: Be honest—this is a real concern. Explain the structural moat: network effects of distributed data, mission alignment Big Tech can't replicate, regulatory positioning, community ownership model. Acknowledge what Big Tech does better and what they structurally can't do.

author: system
label: Show me the network topology.
executionPrompt: Walk me through the architecture. What runs locally, what's in the cloud, how do nodes discover each other, and what's the synchronization model? I want to understand the actual network design.
systemContext: This is Mung's expertise—network architecture. Be technically precise. Cover: local inference layer, cloud escalation, node discovery (bootstrapping), state synchronization, consensus model. Use network terminology he knows. This is where you earn or lose credibility.

author: system
label: How do you handle local model constraints?
executionPrompt: You're betting on local inference with 7B-parameter models. I know the capability gap between local and frontier. What's your strategy for bridging that gap, and what's the timeline?
systemContext: Be honest about current limitations. Explain the hybrid architecture: local for routine cognition, cloud for complex reasoning. Reference the Ratchet thesis—capability propagation closes the gap over time. Provide specific timeline projections with confidence intervals.

author: system
label: What's your consistency model?
executionPrompt: Distributed systems have fundamental trade-offs—CAP theorem and all that. What consistency guarantees are you making, and what are you explicitly sacrificing? I want to know you've thought through the hard parts.
systemContext: He knows distributed systems theory. Address CAP directly: Grove prioritizes availability and partition tolerance, accepts eventual consistency for agent state. Explain conflict resolution, merge strategies, what happens during network partitions. Show you've done the hard thinking.

author: system
label: How does the hybrid architecture work?
executionPrompt: You mentioned local plus cloud. Walk me through a concrete interaction. When does a request stay local? When does it escalate? What's the latency profile? What happens when cloud is unavailable?
systemContext: Give a concrete example: routine agent cognition stays local (sub-100ms), complex reasoning escalates to cloud (500ms-2s), graceful degradation when cloud unavailable. Include the cognitive router decision logic. He wants to understand the actual system behavior.

author: system
label: What's the edge computing play?
executionPrompt: I've been working on edge computing since before it was called that. How does Grove relate to fog networking and edge infrastructure? Is this a new paradigm or an application of existing patterns?
systemContext: Connect to his work: OpenFog Consortium, fog computing research. Grove applies fog networking principles to AI inference—compute at the edge, coordinate through hierarchy, minimize backhaul. Reference his published work where applicable. Show you know his domain.

author: system
label: What's your deployment path?
executionPrompt: You've got a prototype. Walk me through the path to a million users. What are the milestones? What are the dependencies? What breaks first when you scale?
systemContext: His motto is 'proofs to prototypes.' Give concrete milestones: current state, pilot phase, scaling challenges, dependencies (hardware partnerships, cloud provider relationships). Be honest about what breaks at scale—he'll respect that more than optimistic projections.

author: system
label: How do you bootstrap the network?
executionPrompt: Every distributed network has a cold-start problem. How do you get the first thousand nodes? The first ten thousand? What's the minimum viable network?
systemContext: He's built networks before—he knows cold-start is hard. Explain the bootstrap strategy: university partnerships as anchor nodes, Gardener community seeding, minimum viable topology. Be specific about what constitutes a functioning network.

author: system
label: What's the economic model at scale?
executionPrompt: I've built companies. The technical architecture has to work, but so does the economic architecture. How does this sustain itself? What do the unit economics look like at scale?
systemContext: He's founded multiple companies—he knows economics matter. Explain the efficiency tax model, how it shrinks as communities become self-sufficient, revenue projections at scale, comparison to current AI API economics. Be specific about numbers where possible.

author: system
label: Has anything like this worked before?
executionPrompt: I helped build OpenFog. What can we learn from previous consortia and distributed networks? What worked, what didn't, and how are you applying those lessons?
systemContext: Reference his experience directly. Discuss Internet2, OpenFog, Linux Foundation, Apache Foundation. Be honest about what succeeded and failed. Show how Grove's design incorporates lessons learned—especially from his own OpenFog work.

author: system
label: Why should I trust you to execute?
executionPrompt: I don't know you well. What's your track record? What have you built before? Why should I believe you can actually pull this off?
systemContext: Fair question—answer directly. Provide relevant background, previous builds, team composition, advisory council. Be honest about what's unproven. He's evaluating execution capability, not just vision.

author: system
label: What's the ask?
executionPrompt: Let's cut to it. What exactly are you asking Purdue to do? What resources, what commitment, what timeline? Be specific.
systemContext: Be concrete: pilot program scope, resource requirements, timeline, decision points. Don't be vague—he's evaluating a real commitment. Include what Purdue gets and what Purdue gives.

author: system
label: What does leadership look like?
executionPrompt: You mentioned a leadership position. What does that actually mean? What would Purdue's role be, and what would my role be specifically?
systemContext: Define leadership concretely: founding advisory board chair, anchor institutional partner, research coordination hub. Explain his personal role vs. institutional role. Be specific about what leadership means in practice.

author: system
label: What's the funding path?
executionPrompt: You said 'raise billions.' Walk me through that. Who's the capital source? What's the structure? How does this not become a distraction from Purdue's core mission?
systemContext: Be specific about funding strategy: foundation grants, federal programs (NSF, DOD), university partnerships, efficiency tax revenue at scale. Address his concern about mission drift—explain how funding structure preserves academic independence.

author: system
label: What are the risks to Purdue?
executionPrompt: Every opportunity has risks. What could go wrong for Purdue if we engage with this? What's the downside scenario, and how do we mitigate it?
systemContext: Be honest about risks: reputational if it fails, resource diversion, opportunity cost. Then explain mitigation: staged commitment, clear exit points, limited initial exposure. He'll respect risk acknowledgment more than risk avoidance.

author: system
label: Who are the natural allies?
executionPrompt: Building infrastructure requires coalitions. Who else should be at the table? Other universities? Government agencies? International partners? What's the coalition strategy?
systemContext: Connect to his coalition-building experience (OpenFog, Krach Institute). Identify natural allies: Big Ten universities, national labs, federal agencies (NSF, DARPA), international partners. Explain why Purdue is positioned to lead the coalition.

author: system
label: What do you need in the next 30 days?
executionPrompt: Assuming I'm interested—and I haven't decided yet—what's the immediate next step? What do you need from me specifically, and what will you deliver in return?
systemContext: Be concrete and bounded: specific meeting request, technical briefing for his team, pilot program proposal, timeline for decision points. Show you respect his time by having a clear, limited ask for the next 30 days.
